review.title: An Experiment on the Connection between the DLs' Family DL<ForAllPiZero> and the Real World
review.abstract: This paper describes the analysis of a selected testbed of Semantic Web ontologies, by a SPARQL query, which determines those ontologies that can be related to the description logic DL<ForAllPiZero>, introduced in [4] and studied in [9]. We will see that a reasonable number of them is expressible within such computationally efficient language. We expect that, in a long-term view, a temporalization of description logics, and consequently, of OWL(2), can open new perspectives for the inclusion in this language of a greater number of ontologies of the testbed and, hopefully, of the "real world".

sections.heading: 1.1 Description Logics
sections.text: Description Logic (DLs) is a family of formalisms for the representation of knowledge based on logical semantics. They are based on some basic ideas: • basic syntactical "blocks" are atomic concepts (1-ary predicates), atomic roles (2-ary predicates), and individuals (constants); • the meaningfulness of a certain language depends on the use of a series of selected constructors that produce complex concepts and roles emanating from existing ones; • the classification of concepts establishes a hierarchy of subsumption that specifies which concept encompasses or includes another;

sections.heading: 1.4 RDF graphs
sections.text: RDF is a model for displaying information on the Web. The basic idea is that each resource (concept, class, property, object, value, etc.) can be uniquely described by simple properties or by value properties identified. All of this allows to schematize an RDF model using an oriented graph whose nodes represent primitive objects and whose edges identify properties. RDF's limited vocabulary is extended by RDFS (RDF schema), which makes it possible to define classes and properties in a more powerful way. For example, it is possible to define a property as a relationship by specifying its domain and / or range, or to say which class is a subclass of another. From a data-structural point of view, an RDF graph can be viewed as a group of triples of type (subject-predicate object).

sections.text: OWLontologies further expand the vocabulary of RDFS. 8 If RDFS guarantees universality and precision in the construction of knowledge representation, with OWLwe we we achieve such expressivity that we can "argue" about described information and "extract" more, through reasoning. sections.heading: 2.2 Description of the experiment
sections.text: Our analysis aims to select ontologies that correspond to the DL < ен0 > family in order to use them as a study basis for this logic family in the real world. To do this, it is necessary to query as many publicly available ontologies as possible quickly and efficiently. SPARQL queries are conveniently used for this purpose. Management is provided by dOWLphin, a Java library specifically designed to easily load the ontologies and prepare the queries. The underlying library is Jena, one of the most common API collections for the Semantic Web, which is very handy because it can handle triples directly. As a front-end GUI, the QuAny program, also created within the experiment, was used to query against local and remote ontologies and store the corresponding results on the hard disk for future verification.

sections.heading: 2.3 Results and future objectives
sections.text: The query was used to test a significant number of ontologies of the BioPortal, the web portal of the National Center for Biomedical Ontology. This choice was not random, but was motivated mainly by two reasons: the first concerns the large number of ontologies present on the portal and coming from sources of biomedical resources around the world; the second refers to the connection that these ontologies have with the real world in general and with human life and medicine in particular, which are areas that offer several suggestions for reflection on the extent to which knowledge of such important topics can be schematized and presented, and, above all, the role that reasoning could have in the automatic conclusion of new information. Approximately 30% of the ontologies resulted from members of the DL < 0 > language, which raises good hopes for an argument for them, since − remember − w.r.t. shows computational complexity in the NP application area.
